segments.en: Numbered Discourses 6
5. About Dhammika
54. About Dhammika

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā dhammiko jātibhūmiyaṃ āvāsiko hoti sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattasu āvāsesu.
segments.en: Now at that time Venerable Dhammika was a resident in all seven monasteries of his native land.

segments.pli: Tatra sudaṃ āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.
segments.en: There he abused visiting mendicants; he insulted, harmed, attacked, and harassed them.

segments.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
segments.en: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way did not stay. They left, abandoning the monastery.
Then the local lay followers thought to themselves,
“We have supplied the mendicant Saṅgha with robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

segments.pli: Atha ca pana āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
segments.en: But the visiting mendicants don’t stay. They leave, abandoning the monastery.

segments.pli: Ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsan”ti?
segments.en: What is the cause, what is the reason for this?”
Then the local lay followers thought to themselves,

segments.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.
segments.en: “This Venerable Dhammika abuses visiting mendicants; he insults, harms, attacks, and harasses them.

segments.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
segments.en: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way do not stay. They leave, abandoning the monastery.
Why don’t we banish Venerable Dhammika?”

segments.pli: Atha kho jātibhūmakā upāsakā yena āyasmā dhammiko tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then the local lay followers went up to Venerable Dhammika and said to him,
“Sir, please leave this monastery.
You’ve stayed here long enough.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dhammiko tamhā āvāsā aññaṃ āvāsaṃ agamāsi.
segments.en: Then Venerable Dhammika left and went to another monastery.

segments.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.
segments.en: There he abused visiting mendicants; he insulted, harmed, attacked, and harassed them.

segments.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
segments.en: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way did not stay. They left, abandoning the monastery.
Then the local lay followers thought to themselves: …

segments.pli: Atha ca pana āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
Ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsan”ti?
“ayaṃ kho āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.
Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
Atha kho jātibhūmakā upāsakā yenāyasmā dhammiko tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: They said to Venerable Dhammika,
“Sir, please leave this monastery.
You’ve stayed here long enough.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dhammiko tamhāpi āvāsā aññaṃ āvāsaṃ agamāsi.
segments.en: Then Venerable Dhammika left and went to another monastery.

segments.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.
segments.en: There he abused visiting mendicants; he insulted, harmed, attacked, and harassed them.

segments.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
segments.en: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way did not stay. They left, abandoning the monastery.
Then the local lay followers thought to themselves,

segments.pli: Atha ca pana āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
Ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsan”ti?
Atha kho jātibhūmakānaṃ upāsakānaṃ etadahosi: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati … pe ….
Yannūna mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ pabbājeyyāma sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti.
segments.en: “Why don’t we banish Venerable Dhammika from all seven monasteries in our native land?”

segments.pli: Atha kho jātibhūmakā upāsakā yenāyasmā dhammiko tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then the local lay followers went up to Venerable Dhammika and said to him,

segments.pli: “pakkamatu, bhante, āyasmā dhammiko sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, please leave all seven monasteries in our native land.”
Then Venerable Dhammika thought,

segments.pli: “pabbājito khomhi jātibhūmakehi upāsakehi sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehi.
segments.en: “I’ve been banished by the local lay followers from all seven monasteries in my native land.
Where am I to go now?”
He thought,
“Why don’t I go to see the Buddha?”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dhammiko pattacīvaramādāya yena rājagahaṃ tena pakkāmi.
segments.en: Then Venerable Dhammika took his bowl and robe and set out for Rājagaha.

segments.pli: Anupubbena yena rājagahaṃ gijjhakūṭo pabbato yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: Eventually he came to Rājagaha and the Vulture’s Peak. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

segments.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, āgacchasī”ti?
segments.en: “So, Brahmin Dhammika, where have you come from?”

segments.pli: “Pabbājito ahaṃ, bhante, jātibhūmakehi upāsakehi sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, I’ve been banished by the local lay followers from all seven monasteries in my native land.”

segments.pli: “Alaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, kiṃ te iminā, yaṃ taṃ tato tato pabbājenti, so tvaṃ tato tato pabbājito mameva santike āgacchasi.
segments.en: “Enough, Brahmin Dhammika, what’s that to you? Now that you’ve been banished from all of those places, you have come to me.

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sāmuddikā vāṇijā tīradassiṃ sakuṇaṃ gahetvā nāvāya samuddaṃ ajjhogāhanti.
segments.en: Once upon a time, some sea-merchants set sail for the ocean deeps, taking with them a land-spotting bird.

segments.pli: Te atīradakkhiṇiyā nāvāya tīradassiṃ sakuṇaṃ muñcanti.
segments.en: When their ship was out of sight of land, they released the bird.

segments.pli: So gacchateva puratthimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati pacchimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uttaraṃ disaṃ, gacchati dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uddhaṃ, gacchati anudisaṃ.
segments.en: It flew right away to the east, the west, the north, the south, upwards, and in-between.

segments.pli: Sace so samantā tīraṃ passati, tathāgatakova hoti.
segments.en: If it saw land on any side, it went there and stayed.

segments.pli: Sace pana so samantā tīraṃ na passati tameva nāvaṃ paccāgacchati.
segments.en: But if it saw no land on any side it returned to the ship.

segments.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, yaṃ taṃ tato tato pabbājenti so tvaṃ tato tato pabbājito mameva santike āgacchasi.
segments.en: In the same way, now that you’ve been banished from all of those places, you have come to me.

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, rañño korabyassa suppatiṭṭho nāma nigrodharājā ahosi pañcasākho sītacchāyo manoramo.
segments.en: Once upon a time, King Koravya had a royal banyan tree with five trunks called ‘Well Planted’. It was shady and lovely.

segments.pli: Suppatiṭṭhassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, nigrodharājassa dvādasayojanāni abhiniveso ahosi, pañca yojanāni mūlasantānakānaṃ.
segments.en: Its canopy spread over twelve leagues, while the network of roots spread for five leagues.

segments.pli: Suppatiṭṭhassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, nigrodharājassa tāva mahantāni phalāni ahesuṃ;
segments.en: Its fruits were as large as
a rice pot.
And they were as sweet as
pure wild honey.

segments.pli: Suppatiṭṭhassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, nigrodharājassa ekaṃ khandhaṃ rājā paribhuñjati saddhiṃ itthāgārena, ekaṃ khandhaṃ balakāyo paribhuñjati, ekaṃ khandhaṃ negamajānapadā paribhuñjanti, ekaṃ khandhaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇā paribhuñjanti, ekaṃ khandhaṃ migā paribhuñjanti.
segments.en: The king and harem made use of one trunk, the troops another, the people of town and country another, ascetics and brahmins another, and beasts and birds another.

segments.pli: Suppatiṭṭhassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, nigrodharājassa na koci phalāni rakkhati, na ca sudaṃ aññamaññassa phalāni hiṃsanti.
segments.en: No-one guarded the fruit, yet no-one damaged another’s fruits.

segments.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, aññataro puriso suppatiṭṭhassa nigrodharājassa yāvadatthaṃ phalāni bhakkhitvā sākhaṃ bhañjitvā pakkāmi.
segments.en: Then a certain person ate as much as he liked of the fruit, then broke off a branch and left.

segments.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, suppatiṭṭhe nigrodharāje adhivatthāya devatāya etadahosi:
segments.en: Then the deity haunting the royal banyan tree thought,
‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing!

segments.pli: Yāva pāpo manusso, yatra hi nāma suppatiṭṭhassa nigrodharājassa yāvadatthaṃ phalāni bhakkhitvā sākhaṃ bhañjitvā pakkamissati, yannūna suppatiṭṭho nigrodharājā āyatiṃ phalaṃ na dadeyyā’ti.
segments.en: How wicked this person is, to eat as much as they like, then break off a branch and leave! Why don’t I make sure that the royal banyan tree gives no fruit in future?’

segments.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, suppatiṭṭho nigrodharājā āyatiṃ phalaṃ na adāsi.
segments.en: Then the royal banyan tree gave no more fruit.

segments.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, rājā korabyo yena sakko devānamindo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then King Koravya went up to Sakka, lord of gods, and said to him,

segments.pli: ‘yagghe, mārisa, jāneyyāsi suppatiṭṭho nigrodharājā phalaṃ na detī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Please sir, you should know that the royal banyan tree called Well Planted gives no fruit.’

segments.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sakko devānamindo tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi, yathā bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā suppatiṭṭhaṃ nigrodharājaṃ pavattesi ummūlamakāsi.
segments.en: Then Sakka used his psychic powers to will that a violent storm come. And it felled and uprooted the royal banyan tree.

segments.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, suppatiṭṭhe nigrodharāje adhivatthā devatā dukkhī dummanā assumukhī rudamānā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
segments.en: Then the deity haunting the tree stood to one side, miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face.

segments.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sakko devānamindo yena suppatiṭṭhe nigrodharāje adhivatthā devatā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā suppatiṭṭhe nigrodharāje adhivatthaṃ devataṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Sakka went up to that deity, and said,

segments.pli: ‘kiṃ nu tvaṃ, devate, dukkhī dummanā assumukhī rudamānā ekamantaṃ ṭhitā’ti?
segments.en: ‘Why, god, are you standing to one side, miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face?’

segments.pli: ‘Tathā hi pana me, mārisa, bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā bhavanaṃ pavattesi ummūlamakāsī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Because, my good sir, a violent storm came and felled and uprooted my home.’

segments.pli: ‘Api nu tvaṃ, devate, rukkhadhamme ṭhitāya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā bhavanaṃ pavattesi ummūlamakāsī’ti?
segments.en: ‘Well, did you stand by your tree’s duty when the storm came?’

segments.pli: ‘Kathaṃ pana, mārisa, rukkho rukkhadhamme ṭhito hotī’ti?
segments.en: ‘But my good sir, how does a tree stand by its duty?’

segments.pli: ‘Idha, devate, rukkhassa mūlaṃ mūlatthikā haranti, tacaṃ tacatthikā haranti, pattaṃ pattatthikā haranti, pupphaṃ pupphatthikā haranti, phalaṃ phalatthikā haranti.
segments.en: ‘It’s when those who need the tree’s roots, bark, leaves, flowers, or fruit take what they need.

segments.pli: Na ca tena devatāya anattamanatā vā anabhinandi vā karaṇīyā.
segments.en: Yet the deity is not displeased or upset because of this.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, devate, rukkho rukkhadhamme ṭhito hotī’ti.
segments.en: This is how a tree stands by its duty.’

segments.pli: ‘Aṭṭhitāyeva kho me, mārisa, rukkhadhamme bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā bhavanaṃ pavattesi ummūlamakāsī’ti.
segments.en: ‘I was not standing by a tree’s duty when the storm came and felled and uprooted my home.’

segments.pli: ‘Sace kho tvaṃ, devate, rukkhadhamme tiṭṭheyyāsi, siyā te bhavanaṃ yathāpure’ti.
segments.en: ‘God, if you were to stand by a tree’s duty, your home may be as it was before.’

segments.pli: ‘Ṭhassāmahaṃ, mārisa, rukkhadhamme, hotu me bhavanaṃ yathāpure’ti.
segments.en: ‘I will stand by a tree’s duty! May my home be as it was before!’

segments.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sakko devānamindo tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi, yathā bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā suppatiṭṭhaṃ nigrodharājaṃ ussāpesi, sacchavīni mūlāni ahesuṃ.
segments.en: Then Sakka used his psychic power to will that a violent storm come. And it raised up that mighty banyan tree and the bark of the roots was healed.

segments.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, api nu taṃ samaṇadhamme ṭhitaṃ jātibhūmakā upāsakā pabbājesuṃ sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti?
segments.en: In the same way, Brahmin Dhammika, were you standing by an ascetic’s duty when the local lay followers banished you from all seven of the monasteries in your native land?”

segments.pli: “Kathaṃ pana, bhante, samaṇo samaṇadhamme ṭhito hotī”ti?
segments.en: “But sir, how do I stand by an ascetic’s duty?”

segments.pli: “Idha, brāhmaṇa dhammika, samaṇo akkosantaṃ na paccakkosati, rosantaṃ na paṭirosati, bhaṇḍantaṃ na paṭibhaṇḍati.
segments.en: “When someone abuses, annoys, or argues with an ascetic, the ascetic doesn’t abuse, annoy, or argue back at them.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, samaṇo samaṇadhamme ṭhito hotī”ti.
segments.en: That’s how an ascetic stands by an ascetic’s duty.”

segments.pli: “Aṭṭhitaṃyeva maṃ, bhante, samaṇadhamme jātibhūmakā upāsakā pabbājesuṃ sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti.
segments.en: “I was not standing by an ascetic’s duty when the local lay followers banished me from all seven of the monasteries in my native land.”

segments.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sunetto nāma satthā ahosi titthakaro kāmesu vītarāgo.
segments.en: “Once upon a time, there was a Teacher called Sunetta. He was a religious founder and was free of sensual desire.

segments.pli: Sunettassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, satthuno anekāni sāvakasatāni ahesuṃ.
segments.en: He had many hundreds of disciples.

segments.pli: Sunetto satthā sāvakānaṃ brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desesi.
segments.en: He taught them the path to rebirth in the company of Brahmā.

segments.pli: Ye kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sunettassa satthuno brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desentassa cittāni na pasādesuṃ te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjiṃsu.
segments.en: Those lacking confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

segments.pli: Ye kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sunettassa satthuno brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desentassa cittāni pasādesuṃ te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjiṃsu. (1)
segments.en: Those full of confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, mūgapakkho nāma satthā ahosi … pe … (2)
segments.en: Once upon a time there was a teacher called Mūgapakkha …
Aranemi …
Kuddālaka …
Hatthipāla …

segments.pli: … Jotipālo nāma satthā ahosi titthakaro kāmesu vītarāgo.
segments.en: Jotipāla. He was a religious founder and was free of sensual desire.

segments.pli: Jotipālassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, satthuno anekāni sāvakasatāni ahesuṃ.
segments.en: He had many hundreds of disciples.

segments.pli: Jotipālo satthā sāvakānaṃ brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desesi.
segments.en: He taught them the way to rebirth in the company of Brahmā.

segments.pli: Ye kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, jotipālassa satthuno brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desentassa cittāni na pasādesuṃ te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjiṃsu.
segments.en: Those lacking confidence in Jotipāla were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

segments.pli: Ye kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, jotipālassa satthuno brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desentassa cittāni pasādesuṃ te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjiṃsu. (6)
segments.en: Those full of confidence in Jotipāla were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
What do you think, Brahmin Dhammika?

segments.pli: yo ime cha satthāre titthakare kāmesu vītarāge, anekasataparivāre sasāvakasaṃghe paduṭṭhacitto akkoseyya paribhāseyya, bahuṃ so apuññaṃ pasaveyyā”ti?
segments.en: If someone with malicious intent were to abuse and insult these six teachers with their hundreds of followers, would they not make much bad karma?”
“Yes, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yo kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, ime cha satthāre titthakare kāmesu vītarāge anekasataparivāre sasāvakasaṃghe paduṭṭhacitto akkoseyya paribhāseyya, bahuṃ so apuññaṃ pasaveyya.
segments.en: “They would indeed.

segments.pli: Yo ekaṃ diṭṭhisampannaṃ puggalaṃ paduṭṭhacitto akkosati paribhāsati, ayaṃ tato bahutaraṃ apuññaṃ pasavati.
segments.en: But someone who abuses and insults a single person accomplished in view with malicious intent makes even more bad karma.
Why is that?

segments.pli: Nāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, ito bahiddhā evarūpiṃ khantiṃ vadāmi, yathāmaṃ sabrahmacārīsu.
segments.en: Brahmin Dhammika, I say that any injury done by those outside of the Buddhist community does not compare with what is done to one’s own spiritual companions.
So you should train like this:
‘We will have no malicious intent for those who we want to have as our spiritual companions.’
That is how you should train.
Sunetta and Mūgapakkha,
and Aranemi the brahmin,
Hatthipāla the student,
and Kuddālaka were Teachers.
And Jotipāla Govinda
was priest for seven kings.
These six famous teachers,
harmless ones of the past,
were free of the stench of decay, compassionate,
gone beyond the fetter of sensuality.
Detached from sensual desire,
they were reborn in the Brahmā realm.
Many hundreds of
their disciples were also
free of the stench of decay, compassionate,
gone beyond the fetter of sensuality.
Detached from sensual desire,
they were reborn in the Brahmā realm.
A man who insults
with hateful intent
these outside hermits,
free of desire, immersed in samādhi,
makes much bad karma.
But the man who insults
with hateful intent
a single person accomplished in view,
a mendicant disciple of the Buddha,
makes even more bad karma.
You shouldn’t attack a holy person,
who has given up the grounds for views.
This person is called
the seventh of the noble Saṅgha.
They’re not free of desire for sensual pleasures,
and their faculties are still immature:
faith, mindfulness, and energy,
serenity and discernment.
If you attack such a mendicant,
you first hurt yourself.
Having hurt yourself,
you harm the other.
But if you protect yourself,
the other is also protected.
So you should protect yourself.
An astute person is always uninjured.”

suttaplex.blurb: The monk Dhammika annoys both the monks and the layfolk so badly that they banish him. He comes to the Buddha, who consoles him and raises his spirits with a story, while at the same time showing him the error of his ways.
